raw_text:
Cage film's third week at US top
 
 Nicolas Cage movie National Treasure has topped the US and Canada box office for the third week in a row.
 
 National Treasure made $17.1m (£8.8m) in ticket sales from Friday to Sunday, according to studio estimates, taking its total to $110.2m (£56.7m). Comedy Christmas with the Kranks, starring Tim Allen and Jamie Lee Curtis, was in second place. The Polar Express entered in third place while Jude Law film Closer made its debut at number six.
 
 Oliver Stone's big-budget epic Alexander, starring Colin Farrell, followed last week's disappointing sixth-place opening with a slump to seventh place and takings of $4.7m (£2.4m). Critics have savaged the three-hour epic, which reportedly cost $150m (£77m) to make. National Treasure, which sees Cage's character Ben Gates chase a hidden fortune, has been made by Disney Studios. It is Cage's fourth collaboration with Jerry Bruckheimer, who is usually noted for his male-orientated action films.
llama3.2:1b:
National Treasure has topped the US and Canada box office for the third week in a row, earning $17.1m (£8.8m) from Friday to Sunday.

National Treasure is now at $110.2m (£56.7m), while Comedy Christmas with the Kranks was second place with estimated ticket sales of $4.3m (£2.0m).

Closer made its debut in third place, earning $2.5m (£1.3m).
llama3.2:3b: National Treasure topped the US and Canada box office for the third week in a row, earning $17.1m from Friday to Sunday. Comedy Christmas with the Kranks was in second place. Alexander, starring Colin Farrell, fell to seventh place after its disappointing opening. National Treasure has made $110.2m, while critics panned Alexander's $150m production cost.
gemma2:2b:
Nicolas Cage's "National Treasure" topped the US box office for the third week in a row, earning $17.1 million and reaching $110.2 million total. 
Second place went to "Christmas with the Kranks", while "The Polar Express" and "Closer" rounded out the top 3.  "Alexander" experienced a drop in box office performance after its disappointing opening last week.
qwen2.5:0.5b: National Treasure, the third week's third-highest-grossing film in the US and Canada, took $17. 1 million from Friday to Sunday, making a total of $110. 2 million. It was surpassed by Oliver Stone's big-budget epic Alexander with Colin Farrell (8th place). Other well-received films included: National Treasure (6th) directed by Disney Studios, starring Ben Gazzara and Kevin Costner; The Polar Express (7th), a comedy starring Jamie Lee Curtis and the Kranks; and Closer (number 6), which opened in sixth. Oliver Stone's Alexander was the top-grossing film of last week, with $4. 7 million from Friday to Sunday, making it the seventh highest-grossing film overall.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Nicolas Cage's movie "National Treasure" topped the US and Canada box office for three consecutive weeks, grossing $17.1 million from its third weekend, bringing total sales to $110.2 million. It was followed by Tim Allen and Jamie Lee Curtis' comedy "Christmas with the Kranks," and Jude Law's film "Closer" debuted in sixth place with a modest $4.7 million gross. Oliver Stone's $300 million epic "Alexander" slid from fifth to seventh, despite criticism over its three-hour runtime and high production cost of £77 million.
qwen2.5:3b: Nicolas Cage's "National Treasure" topped US and Canada box office for third consecutive week, earning $17.1m in ticket sales from Friday to Sunday, bringing total earnings to $110.2m (£56.7m). Comedy "Christmas with the Kranks" was second, while "The Polar Express" entered at third place. Jude Law's film "Closer" debuted at sixth. Oliver Stone's "Alexander," starring Colin Farrell, dropped from sixth to seventh place with $4.7m (£2.4m) in takings. Critically panned and costing $150m (£77m), it was a disappointment compared to its previous week's performance. "National Treasure" is made by Disney Studios and is Cage's fourth collaboration with Jerry Bruckheimer, known for action films.

 Nicolas Cage's "National Treasure" topped US box office third week with $17.1m, reaching total $110.2m. It was first in comedy, second to "Polar Express."
tinyllama:1.1b: Cage Film's third week in the US and Canada box office is a dominating one, as Nicolas Cage movie National Treasure has surpassed all other competitors with a box office haul of $110m (£56.7m). The latest installment of the action-adventure series has taken first place from the Christmas comedy Comeody (starring Tim Allen and Jamie Lee Curtis), and the Polar Express film entering in third place, with Judy Law's big-budget epic Alexander following last week to take sixth spot. Oliver Stone's Alexander had been expected to perform poorly, but was instead outperformed by a three-hour epic costing $150m (£77m). Critics found National Treasure disappointing with an initial response and the film's fourth collaboration with Jerry Bruckheimer has reportedly cost $150m.
tinydolphin:1.1b:
The third week in a row at the top of the US and Canada box office is National Treasure, starring Nicolas Cage. The film has taken $110.2m (£56.7m), beating the previous record of $97.4m (£48.3m) set by J.J. Abram's sci-fi epic, "The Avengers." 

Comedy Christmas with Tim Allen and Jamie Lee Curtis is in second place with a total haul of $17.1m (£8.8m). The Polar Express, starring Jim Carrey as a Santa Claus-type character, debuted at number six with a $4.7m (£2.4m) opening weekend. 

Oliver Stone's big-budget epic Alexander is in seventh place with a take of $4.7m (£2.4m), its lowest finish to date. The film was released earlier this month and has not been well-received by critics, who have reportedly given the movie a "D" rating. 

Comparatively, Oliver Stone's previous epic, the film adaptation of Dan Brown's novel "The Da Vinci Code," opened at number one with $150m (£77m) and remains in second place with $4.6m (£2.4m), a dip from its opening weekend total.

National Treasure is the fourth film collaboration between Disney Studios and Cage, following the success of "Saving Private Ryan" (1998) and "Pirates of the Caribbean" (2003).

Closer, starring Jude Law, is currently in third place at the box office. Alexander, another big-budget epic, suffered a slump to seventh place after opening weekend, earning $4.7 million from Friday to Sunday. The film has received negative reviews from critics.
